lines.text: Enter VALENTINE and VIOLA in mans attire

lines.speaker: valentine
lines.text: If the duke continue these favours towards you, Cesario, you are like to be much advanced: he hath known you but three days, and already you are no stranger.

lines.speaker: viola
lines.text: You either fear his humour or my negligence, that you call in question the continuance of his love: is he inconstant, sir, in his favours

lines.speaker: viola
lines.text: I thank you. Here comes the count.
Enter DUKE ORSINO, CURIO, and Attendants

lines.speaker: viola
lines.text: On your attendance, my lord here.

lines.speaker: duke orsino
lines.text: Stand you a while aloof, Cesario, Thou knowst no less but all I have unclaspd To thee the book even of my secret soul: Therefore, good youth, address thy gait unto her Be not denied access, stand at her doors, And tell them, there thy fixed foot shall grow Till thou have audience.

lines.speaker: viola
lines.text: Sure, my noble lord, If she be so abandond to her sorrow As it is spoke, she never will admit me.

lines.speaker: duke orsino
lines.text: Be clamorous and leap all civil bounds Rather than make unprofited return.

lines.speaker: viola
lines.text: Say I do speak with her, my lord, what then

lines.speaker: duke orsino
lines.text: O, then unfold the passion of my love, Surprise her with discourse of my dear faith: It shall become thee well to act my woes She will attend it better in thy youth Than in a nuncios of more grave aspect.

lines.speaker: viola
lines.text: I think not so, my lord.

lines.speaker: duke orsino
lines.text: Dear lad, believe it For they shall yet belie thy happy years, That say thou art a man: Dianas lip Is not more smooth and rubious thy small pipe Is as the maidens organ, shrill and sound, And all is semblative a womans part. I know thy constellation is right apt For this affair. Some four or five attend him All, if you will for I myself am best When least in company. Prosper well in this, And thou shalt live as freely as thy lord, To call his fortunes thine.

lines.speaker: viola
lines.text: Ill do my best To woo your lady: yet, a barful strife! Whoeer I woo, myself would be his wife.
